revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2015}}
''''A [[management system]] is the framework of processes and procedures used to ensure that an organization can fulfill all tasks required to achieve its objectives.
After World War II, the reigning paradigm of product-oriented mass production had reached its peak. Examples of management systems at that time are [[Assembly lines|linear assembly lines]], organizational hierarchies of command, [[Quality control|product quality control]] and mass consumption.
Soon afterwards, the [[W. Edwards Deming|Deming]]-[[Joseph M. Juran|Juran]] process-quality teachings spearheaded a new quality orientation (later referred to as [[Total quality management]]) and propelled Japan directly to the post-war process focus (process quality control, [[Just in time (business)|just-in-time]], continuous improvement).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2004-08-29/deming-and-juran-the-kings-of-quality | title=Deming And Juran: The Kings Of Quality | publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek | date=August 2004}}</ref> The US responded by a painful and prolonged product-to-process transformation, ultimately leveling the playing field again by the mid 1980s.
At the end of the 1980s, [[business process reengineering]] focused on the radical redesign of the production process through the reintegration of task, labor and knowledge. As a result, lean, flexible and streamlined production processes were created, capable of fast response and internet-based integration necessary for the upcoming phase of supply chains - [[business-to-business]] (B2B) – as well as demand chains – [[Consumer-to-business|business-to-customer]] (B2C).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bmmagazine.co.uk/in-business/advice/18436/the-evolution-of-management/ | title=The Evolution of Management | publisher=Business Matters | year=May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.strategicleadershipinstitute.net/news/the-historical-evolution-of-management-theory-from-1900-to-present-the-changing-role-of-leaders-in-organizations-/ | title=The Historical Evolution of Management Theory from 1900 to Present: The Changing role of Leaders in Organizations | publisher=Strategic Leadership Institute | last=Bosman | first=Manie | year=January 2009}}</ref>
In the above three stages of '''Evolution of Management Systems''', the competitive advantage was derived almost exclusively from the internal resources of the firm. At the end of the 1980s, a radical fourth shift has occurred: the competitive advantage became increasingly derived from the external resources of the firm – through the extended networks of suppliers and customers.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=4&sid=f425a546-b334-4aff-a38e-a48ccc251d39%40sessionmgr4005&hid=4108 | title=THE EVOLUTION OF MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS | date=March 1970 | last=Ackoff | first=Russell L. | journal=CORS Journal | volume=8 | issue=1 | page=P 1–13 | issn=0574-9638}}</ref>
[[File:Figure 1 Basic scheme product, process, external networks.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 1 Basic scheme: product, process, external networks'''|533x533px]] Figure 1 refers to the basic scheme of production and service delivery process. It represents the traditional linear input-process-output management system. This system has been fixed and unchanging for centuries. The only change has been in terms of changing focus on individual components of the system, emphasizing different parts of this basic scheme.
Although the scheme itself (inputs → process → outputs) remains mostly unchallenged, there are some indications that this business model will undergo major restructurings in the future (in the emerging stages of Evolution of Management Systems). It will become disaggregated and distributed, subjected to non-linear modularity<ref>{{cite journal|last=Slotine|first=Jean-Jacques|title=Modular Stability Tools for Distributed Computation and Control|journal=International Journal of Adaptive Control and Signal Processing|volume=17|url=http://web.mit.edu/nsl/www/preprints/modular.pdf}}</ref> and bringing forth new ways of making things and delivering services. Then it will become reintegrated again, tying together globally distributed components into a unified recycling whole.
== Early stages == All early stages are characterized by changing focus of attention within the unchanging, invariant scheme of Figure 1. The management system has typically focused on:
=== Final product ===
The final product is a primary focus, the production process is considered secondary. Its operations and their sequences are technologically fixed or ‘given’. Product quality is ‘inspected in’, mostly at the end of the process. [[Statistical quality control]], [[inventory control]], cost minimization, mass production, [[assembly line]], work specialization, hierarchies of command, mass consumption, statistical mass markets and forecasting are among the defining characteristics of this stage.
=== Partitioned process === It is the high-quality process that assures the high-quality product. The main focus was on improving of process operations. Quality of the process was understood as the quality of its operations. Powerful new concepts of [[Total Quality Management]] (TQM), [[Continuous Improvement Process]] ([[Kaizen]]) and Just-In-Time (JIT) systems have characterized this stage. Although the operations were being improved, the process architecture and structural sequencing were kept intact and remained technologically ‘given’.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.springer.com/978-3-642-36683-3 | title=The Evolution of the Concept of‘Management Control’ | publisher=Springer | year=2004}}</ref>
=== Integrated process === The focus of attention shifted from operations (circles) to linkages (arrows) – thus changing the process architecture itself. The reengineering of the process, re-integrating individual components into effective, more autonomous and even self-manageable wholes, has characterized this stage.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ansoff|first=H. Igor|title=Conceptual underpinnings of systematic strategic management|journal=European Journal of Operational Research|date=January 1985|volume=19|issue=1|page=P 2–19|issn=0377-2217|doi=10.1016/0377-2217(85)90303-0}}</ref> The production process became a business process and therefore subject to qualitative redesign and reengineering ([[Business process reengineering|BPR]]). Discontinuous improvement and process innovation replaced the piecemeal continuous improvement. Traditional vertical hierarchies of command have flattened out into more horizontal, process-oriented networks. [[Mass customization]], disintermediation, [[knowledge management]] and autonomous teams have started emerging.
== Extended process == [[File:Extended process and Customer Intervention Point.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 2 Extended process and Customer Intervention Point'''|463x463px]] Figure 2 refers to the paradigmatic shift from internal processes expanded into the extended process – including supplier networks and alliances as well as customer self-service, [[mass customization]] and disintermediation – as the increasingly external sources of competitive advantage.
In this recently peaked stage, networks of suppliers and communities of customers have extended the internal process into a functional and competitive whole. Both internal and external sources of knowledge and competitiveness have formed new core competencies. Supply and demand chains management have emerged, in dependence on shifting CIP (Customer Intervention Point). [[Intranets]] and [[extranets]] have provided a communication medium for B2B and B2C exchanges. Quality has become bundled together with cost, speed and reliability..
Today, powerful processes of [[global sourcing]] bring forth and foster a new set of relationships with customers and suppliers. The firm starts disaggregating its production processes, transferring, leasing or selling selected pieces off to a higher-added value operator or coordinator. Any firm can be only as good as is the network of which it is a part. Consequently, the firm has disaggregated and became a network.
== Distributed process == This emerging stage represents the most radical business refocusing so far. Through the [[global sourcing]], sections and components of the internal process are being outsourced to external providers and contractors in search of the highest added value contribution. Long-term alliances are formed and companies are transforming themselves into networks. Network cooperation is replacing corporate competition: ''[[coopetition]]'' emerges. The majority of companies (also the educational and training institutions) could still be the leading global players in this incessant and accelerating paradigm shifting. Globally distributed process ushers in new forms of organization, coordination and modular integration.
[[File:Distributed process and Outsourcing.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 3 Distributed process and Outsourcing'''|466x466px]] Different parts of the extended process are geographically distributed and often spatially remote. In Figure 3, this distribution is represented by sections OS of the process which have been outsourced to higher added-value providers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=O'Connor|first=Gina Colarelli|title=Organizing for Radical Innovation: An Exploratory Study of the Structural Aspects of RI Management Systems in Large Established Firms|journal=Journal of Product Innovation Management|date=November 2006|volume=23|issue=6|page=P 475–497|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=f425a546-b334-4aff-a38e-a48ccc251d39%40sessionmgr4005&vid=5&hid=4108|issn=0737-6782|doi=10.1111/j.1540-5885.2006.00219.x}}</ref>
Although the Stage 5 (Figure 3) represents the most radical business refocusing emerging so far, still rapidly emerging kernels of the next stage (Figure 4) is taking shape. The evolutionary process, driven by relentless global search for maximum added value, is clearly accelerating. Management systems paradigm or business model, after a century of relative invariance, is becoming a new dynamic source of competitive advantage. Radically distributed supply and demand chains of Stage 5 will clearly have to be coordinated and reintegrated on a global scale. Reintegration processes are proceeding under increasing environmental pressures. The search for added value, after exploring traditional global resources, is now turning towards reuse, recycling, recovery and remanufacturing as new sources of maximizing added value. Innovation in business models will become a norm.
== Recycled process == [[File:Recycled Process and Global Sourcing.PNG|thumb|'''Figure 4 Recycled Process and Global Sourcing'''|465x465px]] During the process of utilizing added value, the asset-recovery practices expand quickly to a majority of products and services (Dell, IBM, Xerox). New products are being designed for extended life spans and multiple profit cycles. Reverse logistics and [[Reverse logistics|reverse logistics management]] (RLM) are adding new loops to the traditionally unidirectional processes of supply chains.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two Steps Forward, One Step Back...|url=http://www.infosys.com/industries/retail/white-papers/Documents/reverse-logistics-management.pdf|publisher=Infosys|author=Saty Chawla}}</ref> Old supply chains have become demand chains and now reverse value chains, demonstrating that value can be added in both directions: through the forward pass of production as well as through the backward pass of recovery and remanufacture. Concepts of easy disassembly, durability, reuse and recycling are built in into equipment design.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Glassey|first=Olivier|title=Exploring the weak signals of starts-ups as a folksonomic system|journal=Technology Analysis & Strategic Management|date=April 2009|volume=21|issue=3|page=P 321–332|doi=10.1080/09537320902750632|issn=0953-7325}}</ref>
Figure 4 refers to closed-loop management system and it represents the Stage 6 of the '''Evolution of Management Systems'''. The new loops in the figure are not just traditional information feedback loops, but real business processes of collection, disassembly, reprocessing and reassembly activities (operations).<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://hbr.org/product/double-loop-management-making-strategy-a-continuous-process/an/B0007A-PDF-ENG | title=Double-Loop Management: Making Strategy a Continuous Process | last=Kaplan | first=Robert | journal=Harvard Business Review | year=July 2000}}</ref> The conventional open-ended linear processes are being redesigned towards closure.
New loops of recycled products and materials, [[energy recovery]] and knowledge renewal are being created within [[Global Sourcing and Supply (GSS)|global-sourcing]] (GS) networks. Product reuse/remanufacture relies on a high residual value which gives a good head start for added value maximization. The system becomes organizationally closed and potentially long-term sustainable or even trans-generations self-sustainable.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/high_tech_telecoms_internet/the_great_transformer | title=The great transformer: The impact of the Internet on economic growth and prosperity | publisher=McKinsey Global Institute | last=Roxburgh | first=Charles | year=October 2011}}</ref> The "openness" and customization of the product design, upgradeable products, flexible product platforms, mutability and waste-free strategies are being implemented.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sas.com/content/dam/SAS/en_us/doc/whitepaper2/emerging-green-intelligence-104141.pdf | title=Business Analytics and Corporate Sustainability | publisher=BusinessWeek Research Services | year=2009 | page=10}}</ref> However, in this latest stage, new employee skills and managerial knowledge, as well as essential mass customization mindset are yet to be produced, maintained and renewed. Eliminating non-value added resources is still necessary. Integrating production system elements and work functions still needs time to evolve.
== Evolutionary spiral == [[File:The evolutionary spiral of Six Management Systems (SMS).PNG|'''Figure 5 The evolutionary spiral of Six Management Systems (SMS)'''|368x368px]]
Evolutionary spiral of the six management systems (SMS) are indicated in Figure 5.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sei.cmu.edu/reports/01sr005.pdf | title=Spiral Development and Evolutionary Acquisition | publisher=Carnegie Mellon Software Engineering Institute | author=W. J. Hansen}}</ref>
It is appropriate to notice that six-management-system evolution is progressing in an accelerated fashion, the periods of stasis are getting shorter and revolutions are occurring faster. Individual management systems are beginning to overlap and their boundaries are getting blurred. An era of continuous change in business models and management systems emerges: the search for competitive advantage (one over the other) becomes relentless, strenuous and resources depleting. Cooperation networks have to merge into larger entities, reducing competition and expanding collaboration. The search for collaborative advantage (for both jointly) will become the new mode of economic behavior.
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * Zeleny, Milan (2006) "Innovation Factory: Production of Value-Added Quality and Innovation," ''Economics and Management'', 9, 4, pp. 58–65. * Zeleny, Milan (2007) "The mobile society: effects of global sourcing and network organization"’, ''Int. J. Mobile Learning and Organization'', Vol. 1, No. 1, pp. 30–40. * "Knowledge of Enterprise: Knowledge Management or Knowledge Technology?" ''[[International Journal of Information Technology & Decision Making]]'',1(2002)2, pp. 181–207. * "Entering the Era of Networks: Global Supply and Demand Outsourcing Networks and Alliances," in: ''Quantitative Methoden der Logistik und des Supply Chain Management'', edited by M. Jacquemin, R. Pibornik, and E. Sucky, Verlag Dr. Kovač, Hamburg, 2006, pp. 85–97. * "The mobile society: effects of global sourcing and network organization"’, ''Int. J. Mobile Learning and Organization'', Vol. 1, No. 1, 2007, pp. 30–40. * "Strategy and strategic action in the global era: overcoming the knowing-doing Gap", ''Int. J. Technology Management'', Vol. 43, Nos. 1-3, 2008, pp. 64–75.
[[Category:Management systems]]

'''Slavery has been forbidden''' in the state of [[Minnesota]] since that state's [[admission to the Union]] in 1858. The second section of the first Article of [[Constitution of Minnesota|the state's constitution]], drafted in 1857, provides that:
There shall be neither slavery nor involuntary servitude in the State otherwise there is the punishment of crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.{{cite web|url=http://www.mnhs.org/library/constitution/pdf/republicanversion.pdf|format=PDF|title=Constitution of the State of Minnesota|website=Mnhs.org|accessdate=26 October 2017}}
==Colonial period== {{main|Slavery in New France}} During early [[History of Wisconsin|European exploration]], the area of present-day Minnesota was part of [[New France]] and, as such, was governed by [[Slavery in New France|its slavery laws]]. ==United States territory== The first legislation against slavery was the [[Northwest Ordinance]] of 1787, which forbade slavery in the [[Northwest Territory]], which included those parts of Minnesota that are east of the Mississippi. However, territorial laws and practices allowed human bondage to continue in various forms. Territorial governors [[Arthur St. Clair]] and [[Charles Willing Byrd]] supported slavery and did not enforce the ordinance.{{cite book|title=Slavery in the Upper Mississippi Valley, 1787–1865: A History of Human Bondage in Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin|last=Lehman|first=Christopher P.|year=2011|isbn=978-0786458721|p=27}} ===Dred Scott=== [[Dred Scott]] and his wife Harriet Scott were purchased as slaves in Missouri by an army officer. In 1837 their master took them with him to [[Fort Snelling]] in what later became Minnesota but was then a part of the [[Wisconsin Territory]] . In 1857, the year before Minnesota became a state, the United States Supreme Court ruled in [[Scott v. Sanford]] that the Scotts' residence in Minnesota did not make them free, and they still had the status of slaves after they returned to Missouri. ==See also== *[[Slavery in the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{History of slavery in the United States}} [[Category:African-American history of Minnesota]] [[Category:History of Minnesota|Slavery]] [[Category:Slavery in the United States by state|Minnesota]] [[Category:History of slavery]] [[Category:History of Minnesota]]

{{Infobox dot-com company | name = Hootsuite Media, Inc. | logo = Hootsuite logo.svg | logo_size = 250px | screenshot = [[File:HootSuite Social Media Management System.jpg|290px]]
''The Hootsuite Dashboard'' | location = 5 East 8th Avenue
Vancouver, V5T 1R6
Canada{{cite web|url=http://hootsuite.com/contact |title=Contact Us |publisher=Hootsuite |accessdate=February 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225175449/http://hootsuite.com/contact |archivedate=February 25, 2013 |df= }} | founder = [[Ryan Holmes]], Dario Meli, David Tedman | industry = Internet | url = https://hootsuite.com | registration = Free, Pro, Team, Business, Enterprise | language = [[Multilingual]]{{cite web | url=https://translate.hootsuite.com/ | title=Hootsuite Translations Project | publisher=Hootsuite | accessdate=26 June 2014}} | company_type = Private | foundation = Vancouver, BC, Canada (2008) | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Ryan Holmes (CEO)
Greg Twinney (COO/CFO)
Penny Wilson (CMO){{cite web | url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/hootsuite/ | title=Hootsuite Crunchbase Profile | publisher="Crunchbase" | accessdate=March 15, 2012}} | num_employees = Over 1000 (May 2016). Was 600 (Jun 2014){{cite web | url=https://hootsuite.com/about/careers | title=CAREERS-Build something big with us | publisher=Hootsuite | accessdate=26 June 2014}} | website_type = [[Social media#Managing social media|Social media management]], [[social networking service]] | num_users = Over 16 million (March 2018){{cite news|last=Hootsuite Press Releases|title=Hootsuite nabs $50M in growth capital for its social media management platform, passes 16M customers|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/03/15/hootsuite-raises-50m-more-for-its-social-media-management-platform-passes-16m-customers/|accessdate=7 August 2018|date=15 March 2018}} | launch_date = {{Start date and age|2008|12}} | current_status = Active }} '''Hootsuite''' is a social media management platform, created by [[Ryan Holmes]] in 2008.[http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2009/05/14/hootsuite-for-president-obama-that-is/ "Hootsuite for President, Obama that is"], ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]'' The system’s user interface takes the form of a [[dashboard (web administration)|dashboard]], and supports social network integrations for [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], [[Instagram]], [[LinkedIn]], [[Google+]] and [[YouTube]]. Additional integrations are available via Hootsuite’s App Directory, including [[Reddit]], [[Storify]], [[Tumblr]], and [[Marketo]].{{cite web | url=http://appdirectory.hootsuite.com/ | title=Hootsuite - App Directory | publisher=Hootsuite | accessdate=26 June 2014}} Based in [[Vancouver]], Hootsuite has close to 1,000 staff members located in 13 locations, including [[Toronto]], [[Bucharest]] and [[Mexico City]]. The company has more than 15 million users in over 175 countries. ==History== In 2008, Holmes needed a tool to manage multiple social media networks at his digital services agency, Invoke Media.[http://www.webpronews.com/topnews/2009/07/31/twitter-client-hootsuite-20-is-now-available "Ivan Fernandes, MediaCom Global Director, Social Media Technology, interviews Ryan Holmes, CEO of Hootsuite"]. MediaCom. Retrieved March 21, 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090803161628/http://www.webpronews.com/topnews/2009/07/31/twitter-client-hootsuite-20-is-now-available |date=August 3, 2009 }} Finding that there was no product in the market offering all the features he sought, Holmes, along with [[Dario Meli]], [[David Tedman]], and the Invoke team, chose instead to develop a platform of their own that would be able to organize their many social media accounts and networks.[http://mashable.com/2010/10/21/startup-tips-hootsuite/ "5 Tips for Startup Success From a Co-Founder of Hootsuite"]. Mashable. Retrieved March 21, 2012. The first iteration of this social media management system launched on November 28, 2008 in the form of a Twitter dashboard called BrightKit.[https://www.straight.com/article-175315/brightkit-makes-using-multiple-twitter-accounts-easy/ "BrightKit makes using multiple Twitter accounts easy"]. Vancouver Free Press, #whatsup. Retrieved March 21, 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118020318/http://www.straight.com/article-175315/brightkit-makes-using-multiple-twitter-accounts-easy/ |date=November 18, 2011 }} Recognizing that many other individuals and organizations across the world were facing similar problems with managing multiple social accounts, Holmes decided that BrightKit could be the solution for other businesses also looking to organize their own social networks. The launch of BrightKit had a very positive reception, thanks to its clean interface and publishing capabilities.[http://mashable.com/2008/12/03/brightkit/ "BrightKit: The Shiniest Twitter Scheduler and Tracker Yet"]. Mashable. Retrieved March 21, 2012. In February 2009, Holmes offered a $500 prize for renaming the platform, and used crowdsourced suggestions from the dashboard’s 100,000+ users as contest submissions.[http://www.eesipeo.com/newsletters/43 "What You Should Outsource to Amp Up Efficiency"]. eESI PeopleTalk. Retrieved March 21, 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528211942/http://www.eesipeo.com/newsletters/43 |date=May 28, 2012 }} The winning idea was Hootsuite, a moniker submitted by a user named Matt Nathan[http://www.techvibes.com/blog/brightkit-follower-sources-new-hootsuite-name "BrightKit follower-sources new Hootsuite name"]. TechVibes. Retrieved March 21, 2012. and based upon "Owly", the dashboard’s owl logo, as a [[word play]] on the French expression "tout de suite", meaning "right now". In November 2009, the Hootsuite dashboard expanded its offering to support Facebook and LinkedIn, and the capability to use Twitter Lists.[http://mashable.com/2009/11/24/hootsuite-adds-support-for-facebook-linkedin-and-twitter-lists/ "Hootsuite Adds Support for Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter Lists"]. Mashable. Retrieved March 21, 2012. In December 2009, Hootsuite spun off from Invoke Media and launched officially as an independent company, Hootsuite Media, Inc. That same month, Hootsuite received $1.9 million in funding from Hearst Interactive Media, Blumberg Capital, and prominent angel investors Leo Group LLC and Geoff Entress.[https://techcrunch.com/2010/01/08/hootsuite-raises-1-9-million-for-social-media-dashboard/ "Hootsuite Raises $1.9 Million for Social Media Dashboard"]. TechCrunch. Retrieved March 21, 2012. In March 2012, OMERS Ventures, the venture capital investment arm of the [[Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System]], invested $20 million, valuing the company at US$200 million.[http://adage.com/article/digital/hootsuite-20m-investment-canadian-pension-fund/233780/ "Hootsuite Gets $20M from Canadian Pension Fund"]. AdAge. Retrieved March 29, 2012.{{cite web|title=Confirmed: Canadian VC Firm OMERS Ventures Takes $20M Stake In Hootsuite At $200M Valuation|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/03/29/confirmed-canadian-vc-firm-omers-ventures-takes-20m-stake-in-hootsuite-at-200m-valuation/|work=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL Inc|accessdate=4 August 2013|author=Ingrid Lunden|date=29 March 2012}} OMERS did not buy its stake directly in the company, but rather bought private shares in a secondary transaction from a handful of employees and early investors, said Holmes.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/29/hootsuite-venture-idUSL2E8QS1EY20120329 "Hootsuite cashes out through secondary markets"]. Reuters. Retrieved March 29, 2012. In May 2012, Hootsuite subsequently raised US$50 million in a [[Series A round]], following rumours.{{cite web|title=Hootsuite: $165 Million Series B 'Takes the Pressure Off'|url=http://www.inc.com/francesca-fenzi/hootsuite-triples-down-on-series-b-funding.html?cid=em01011week31day01b|work=Inc.com|publisher=Inc.com|accessdate=4 August 2013|author=FRANCESCA LOUISE FENZI|date=1 August 2013}}{{cite web|title=Hootsuite Is Raising $50M At A $500M Valuation|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/05/03/hootsuite-is-raising-50m-at-a-500m-valuation/|work=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL Inc|accessdate=4 August 2013|author=Ingrid Lunden|date=3 May 2013}} In July 2012, an employee informed ''Forbes'' magazine that the company's team consisted of 200 employees at that time.{{cite web|publisher=[[Forbes]]|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/johngreathouse/2012/07/10/hiring-tools-used-by-hyper-growth-companies-pinterest-tumblr-hootsuite-klout-posterous-bitly-and-mashable/|title=Social Hiring Tools Used By Hyper Growth Companies: Pinterest, Tumblr, Hootsuite, Klout, Posterous, Bitly And Mashable|accessdate=2012-07-11}} In September 2012, Hootsuite acquired Seesmic, a customer relationship management system and competitor. On August 1, 2013, the company announced that it had raised US$165 million in Series B funding from [[Insight Venture Partners]], followed by [[Accel Partners]] and OMERS—all three will now have a seat on Hootsuite's board. Holmes also said the company was looking to make at least two unnamed acquisitions, in addition to employing 100 overseas employees. In February 2017, Hootsuite announced its acquisition of AdEspresso, a digital advertisement manager, and LiftMetrix, a leading social media analytics company.{{cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/life/872011/hootsuite-buys-new-york-based-liftmetrix|title=Hootsuite Buys New York-Based LiftMetrix|publisher=The Georgia Straight|first=Charlie|last=Smith|date=February 22, 2017|access-date=May 2, 2017}} In March 2018, Hootsuite announced $50 million in growth capital from CIBC Innovation Banking.{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/03/15/hootsuite-raises-50m-more-for-its-social-media-management-platform-passes-16m-customers/|title=Hootsuite nabs $50M in growth capital for its social media management platform, passes 16M customers – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-20}} ==Service== The service is commonly used to manage online brands and to submit messages to a variety of social media services, including [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], [[Google+]] and [[Mixi]]. Companies and organizations known to use Hootsuite include [[Facebook]], the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]], [[HBO]], [[Martha Stewart Media]], [[Virgin Group]], [[SXSW]], [[Panasonic]], [[Zappos]], [[Gap (clothing retailer)|The Gap]] and [[Large Hadron Collider|LHC]].[https://venturebeat.com/2009/07/30/hootsuite-the-white-houses-twitter-client-opens-to-public/ "Hootsuite helps you manage your brand on Twitter (hey, it works for the White House)"]. VentureBeat. Retrieved July 4, 2010. Hootsuite provides a browser-based dashboard that allows users to keep updated on their Twitter account. There are both full and lite versions of the service.[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/140-proof-powers-advertising-for-hootsuites-android-and-iphone-apps-85948857.html "140 Proof Powers Advertising for Hootsuite's Android and iPhone Apps"]. Press release. Retrieved July 4, 2010. Hootsuite uses the [[URL shortener]] ''ow.ly'' to shorten URLs submitted to its service.[http://blog.hootsuite.com/htly-owly/ "Ow.ly and Ht.ly ~ Choose Bar or Non-bar URL Shortener for Hootsuite"]. Hootsuite. Retrieved July 4, 2010. ==Business== The company behind the service is based in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]], and its [[chief executive officer]] is Ryan Holmes.[http://www.nationalpost.com/rss/Keeping+tabs+your+brand/3036293/story.html "Keeping tabs on your brand"]. ''The National Post''. Retrieved July 4, 2010. The company's business strategy allows users free basic service with payment for additional features. The company plans to monetize 3 to 5 percent of the service's most active accounts, which are generally owned by major brands such as [[Condé Nast Publications|Conde Nast]], [[AOL]], [[Banana Republic]], and [[Dell]]. In January 2010, the Hootsuite company was spun out of [[Invoke Media]] after [[venture capital]] firms [[Blumberg Capital]] and [[Hearst Corporation|Hearst Interactive Media]] raised $2 million in financing for the company. Localized versions of Hootsuite are available in Japanese, Spanish, Portuguese, and German, and 50 more languages are planned to be added.[https://www.biv.com/article/2010/6/hootsuite-explains-revenue-generation-strategy/ "Hootsuite explains revenue generation strategy"]. ''Business in Vancouver''. Retrieved July 4, 2010. Hootsuite's team continues to contact media organizations to help them manage their online brands, by meeting with groups such as [[Time Inc.]] and its subsidiary magazines, including ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', ''[[InStyle]]'', and ''[[This Old House]]''. As of June 2010, the service manages over one million social media accounts for 400,000 unique users. In September 2014, Hootsuite's New Enterprise customers included [[Telekom Malaysia]], [[Singapore Press Holdings]], [[Brooklyn Public Library]], [[Cambridge University Press]], Red Carnation Hotels and [[Hyland Software|Hyland Software Inc.]][https://hootsuite.com/about/press-releases/hootsuite-acquisition-growth Hootsuite Announces Acquisition of Brightkit, Continues Explosive Growth] In 2017 Hootsuite had more than 15 million users worldwide. ==Reception== The Hootsuite software has won awards from [[Mashable]] at their Open Web Awards 2009,[http://mashable.com/2009/12/16/open-web-awards-2009-50-winners/ "Open Web Awards 2009: The Winners"]. Mashable. Retrieved July 4, 2010. the Canadian New Media Award,[http://www.invokemedia.com/hootsuite-wins-canadian-new-media-award-and-more/ "HootSuite wins Canadian New Media Award and more"]. Invoke Media. Retrieved July 4, 2010. the [[Shorty Awards]],[http://blog.hootsuite.com/hootsuite-wins-best-app-at-shorty-awards/ "HootSuite wins best app at Shorty Awards"]. Hootsuite. Retrieved July 4, 2010. and "Best Twitter App" from Australia's [[mX (newspaper)|mX newspaper]]."Another historic win for Obama". MX (Australia). December 17, 2009. It was a 2012 nominee for the [[Webby Award]]s.{{cite web|publisher=Hootsuite|url=http://blog.hootsuite.com/webby-2012/|title=HootSuite is a 2012 Webby Awards Nominee ~ Vote for Us|accessdate=2012-07-26}} ==Competition== Hootsuite is competing in a marketplace for social media dashboard tools or platforms, where marketers are focused on social media management for their clients' [[Social media marketing#Engagement|web engagement]] activities. Hootsuite's best known competitors include [[Spredfast]] and [[Sprout Social]].{{cite web |url=http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/hootsuite/competitors |title=Hootsuite Competitors |website=CrunchBase}} Each of the big three dashboards pursues innovation strategies that emulate the most recent feature enhancements of the other two; for example, [[TweetDeck]] launched with a desktop application based on the [[Adobe AIR]] platform, and eventually [[Seesmic]] rolled out its own Desktop version. Additional competition includes the [[social media]] and [[media monitoring]] niche, such as Mention or Metricool, which offers real-time web and social media monitoringPatel, Neil. (12 May 2015) http://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/copywriting-tips-improve-conversions. HubSpot. in multiple languages,[https://hazima.wordpress.com/2015/06/03/six-tools-to-use-to-monitor-mentions-on-blogs-and-social-media/ Six tools to use to monitor mentions on blogs and social media. | Ananza NOTs عنانزه] and is designed to provide alerts on a desktop and smart devices.[http://marketingshared.com/resources/ Resources | Marketing Shared] Within financial services, companies like [[Gremln]] provide social media publishing tools that help companies meet strict compliance rules. Other competition in this space includes platforms that appeal to niche segments, such as [[Octopusocial]], which provides a social media marketing platform designed for [[Business-to-business|B2B]] social media{{cite web|last=Miles|first=Stephanie|title=Oktopost Review – Sophisticated Social Media Marketing|url=http://www.getapp.com/blog/oktopost-review/|publisher=GetApp|accessdate=25 March 2014}} and [[content marketing]]. In 2015, companies like Tiempy and Everypost arose in Latin America to compete in the same market, bringing easy to understand tools that non-expert users can utilize. CoSchedule is another online marketing calendar that allows users to easily schedule through social media in one simple step, keeping all social and content in one place, providing a "unified workflow."{{Cite web|url=https://blog.twentyoverten.com/whats-the-best-social-media-app-for-your-business/|title=What’s the Best Social Media Scheduling App For Your Business?|website=Twenty Over Ten|language=en|access-date=2017-12-07}} Hootsuite bought out [[Seesmic]] in September 2012.[https://www.wired.com/business/2012/09/hootsuite-buys-seesmic/ As Twitter Tightens Its Grip, Hootsuite Buys Seesmic] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * [http://blogs.vancouversun.com/2009/05/14/hootsuite-for-president-obama-that-is/ "Hootsuite for President, Obama that is"] at ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]'' * [https://www.techinasia.com/sociocaster-social-media-tool-startup/ "Sociocaster wants to be Hootsuite for Indonesia"] at TechInAsia ==External links== * [https://hootsuite.com/ Official Website] * {{crunchbase}} * [http://www.hallaminternet.com/2013/how-to-use-hootsuite/ "How to Use Hootsuite for Better Twitter Management"] at Hallam Internet * [http://blog.hootsuite.com/become-hootsuite-ambassador-2014/ "Becoming a Hootsuite Ambassador"] at Hootsuite Blog {{Vancouver Corporations}} {{Twitter navbox}} [[Category:Benefit corporations]] [[Category:Companies based in Vancouver]] [[Category:Email marketing software]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2008]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in Canada]] [[Category:Social networking websites]] [[Category:Technology companies of Canada]] [[Category:Twitter services and applications]]

{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Indians in Kenya |image = |poptime = |popplace = [[Nairobi]], [[Mombasa]] |langs = [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Hindustani language|Hindustani]], [[Odia language|Odia]] (native languages)
[[English language|English]], [[Swahili language|Swahili]] (working languages) |rels = [[Hinduism]]{{·}}[[Islam]]{{·}}[[Sikhism]]{{·}}[[Christianity]]{{·}}[[Jainism]] |related-c = [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Non-resident Indian and Person of Indian Origin]] and other [[Indo-Aryan peoples]] }} '''Indians in Kenya''' (also referred to as '''Kenyan Asians''') are citizens and residents of [[Kenya]] with ancestral roots in the [[Indian subcontinent]]. Most are found in the major urban areas of [[Nairobi]] and [[Mombasa]], with others living in rural areas. Significant Indian migration to modern-day Kenya began following the creation of the British [[East Africa Protectorate]] in 1895, which had strong infrastructure links with [[Bombay]] in [[British Raj|British-ruled India]]. ==Terminology== In Kenya, the word ''Asian'' usually refers specifically to people of [[South Asian]] ancestry ([[Pakistan]]is, [[India]]ns, [[Bangladesh]]is and [[Sri Lanka]]ns).Vandenberg, Paul, ''The African-Asian Divide: Analyzing Institutions and Accumulation in Kenya'', Routledge, 2013, page 227 Prior to the [[partition of India]], those of South Asian ancestry were referred to as Indians; however after 1947 the term ''Asian'' also started being used.Sahoo, Ajaya Kumar and Sheffer, Gabriel, ''Diaspora and Identity: Perspectives on South Asian Diaspora'', Routledge, 2006, page 95 ==History== ===Early history=== [[Vasco da Gama]] recorded encountering Indian merchants along the coast of east Africa in the late 15th century. In [[Malindi]] he obtained the service of a [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] speaking sailor to navigate ships across the [[Indian ocean]] to [[Calicut]].Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 10 The [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese]] soon came to monopolise trade across the Indian ocean and displace the existing [[Arabs|Arab]] commercial dominance in the region. Although this affected India's commerce with East Africa, some Indians succeeded in becoming accountants and bankers for the Portuguese as they had been for the Arabs.Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 11 By the early part of the 19th century, small numbers of Indian merchants could be found settled across the trading posts of East Africa. Their interests were enhanced when [[Said bin Sultan]] the [[Muscat and Oman|Sultan of Muscat and Oman]], subjected to the emergence of British naval supremacy in the Indian ocean and direct British political support for Indian merchants along the East African coast, adopted a series of favourable policies towards Indians in the region. In 1887 the [[Imperial British East Africa Company|British East Africa Association]] was founded with its base in [[Bombay]]. The following year the Association was given a royal charter, becoming the Imperial British East Africa Company and moving its base to [[Mombasa]]. Although now based in Africa, the company had a strong Indian orientation, employing guards, police officers, clerks and accountants from Bombay.Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 13 ===East Africa Protectorate=== Significant Indian migration to modern day Kenya began following the creation of the [[East Africa Protectorate]] in 1895. The Protectorate took over the assets and personnel of the Imperial British East Africa Company and hence its Indian orientation. The rupee was instituted as the currency of the Protectorate and the legal system became an extension of Indian law. Among the local Indian ethnic populace, the vast majority of administrative roles were filled by [[Konkani people|Konkani]] [[Goans]], [[Parsis]] and [[Gujaratis]], whilst the ranks of the British officered police and army mainly consisted of [[Punjabis]]. Between 1896 and 1901, some 32,000 indentured labourers were recruited from India to construct the [[Uganda railway]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/762515.stm |title=Kenya's Asian heritage on display |publisher=BBC News |date=2000-05-24 |accessdate=2017-09-02}} Construction of the railway was a remarkable engineering feat; however, approximately 2,500 labourers died during construction (about four deaths for each mile of track laid) and the project was notorious for the [[Tsavo maneaters]]. Once the railway was completed, some of these labourers voluntarily settled in the Protectorate and brought family from India. The railway had opened the interior to trade, and many soon began migrating away from the coastal cities. Over the following years large numbers of Gujaratis and Punjabis migrated freely seeking to utilise new economic possibilities in the Protectorate . These migrants often came with family members or members of the same village or caste.Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 15 Many Asians settled in the new town of [[Nairobi]], which had been the capital of the British protectorate since 1905. Unlike black Africans, Asians were permitted to reside legally in Nairobi in what was then a burgeoning white settler town.Hake, Andrew. 1977. African Metropolis: Nairobi’s Self-Help City. London: Sussex University Press. One of the most significant early pioneers was [[Alibhai Mulla Jeevanjee|A. M. Jeevanjee]]. In 1890 his company A.M. Jeevanjee of [[Karachi]] was awarded the contract to supply labour for the building of the Uganda railway, and he subsequently went on to establish himself as the pre-eminent Asian businessman in the new colony. He established Kenya's first newspaper now known as [[The Standard (Kenya)|The Standard]] in 1901 and was the first non-white to be elected to the Legislative Council in 1910. Such was his success that in 1904 it was estimated that he owned half of Mombassa and the greater part of Nairobi.Patel, Zarina, Alibhai Mulla Jeevanjee, East African Publishers, 2002, Page 13 In 1900 the Mombasa Indian Association was established on the initiative of L.M Savle, and with the backing of wealthy businessmen [[Allidina Visram]] and the Jevanjee brothers, and became the first political organisation in the protectorate to represent the interests of Asians.Howard Schwartz, The Rise and Fall of Philanthropy in East Africa: The Asian Contribution, Routledge, 5 Jul 2017 Regional branches later emerged, including in Nairobi in 1906 which soon became more influential than the Mombasa association. To co-ordinate the aims of the different branches, the British East Africa Indian Association was formed in 1907, however it soon became representative of only local interests and remained relatively unimportant. In 1914 the [[Kenya Indian Congress|East African Indian National Congress]] was established in Mombasa and was modelled on the [[Indian National Congress]]. During the [[First World War]] the militant anti-imperialist [[Ghadar Party]] established a branch in East Africa, and attracted support from a number of the Asian community.Durrani, Shiraz, Never Be Silent: Publishing and Imperialism 1884-1963, Vita Books, 25 Nov 2016 The British authorities took a serious view of what they regarded as the Ghadar party's political terrorism, and sentenced a number of members to death for either belonging to the party or possessing seditious material. ===Kenya Colony=== By the early 1920s, there was a sizeable Asian population who demanded a greater role in the developing political life of what became [[Kenya Colony]]. Racial hostilities gradually intensified in the 1920s; however, Indians, who enjoyed significantly greater economic strength than black Africans, had greater bargaining power with the colonial government. As early as 1920, they turned down the offer of two seats on the legislative council as this was not representative of the size of their community. Tensions with Europeans remained high until 1927 when Indians won the right to five seats on the council, compared to eleven reserved for the Europeans. Both parties prevented any African representation.{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=September 2018}} After the [[Second World War]], Asians were found in all occupations in Nairobi and the townships: in business, the police force, bureaucracy, and the professions.J. Murray-Brown, Kenyatta (London, 1972), p. 83. Their commercial skills contributed to the economic development and prosperity of Kenya and the rest of East Africa.A history of the Asians in East Africa (Oxford, 1969), ch. 1. The 1950s saw increased sentiment against the inequalities of colonial rule, and many Asians were at the forefront of the push for increased rights. These included: [[Pio Gama Pinto]] founder of the [[Kenya African National Union]] newspaper, [[Makhan Singh (Kenyan trade unionist)|Makhan Singh]] who is regarded as laying the foundations of Kenyan trade unionism, and [[Achhroo Ram Kapila|A.R. Kapila]] and [[Fitz Remedios Santana de Souza|Fitz de Souza]] renowned in the legal profession for their representation of those accused of [[Mau Mau uprising|Mau Mau]] links. By 1962, the Asian community had firmly established their dominance within the urban economy. Despite accounting for only 2 percent of the overall population, they constituted one-third of the population of Nairobi, where their businesses dominated the main street.Sowell, Thomas (1996) Migrations and Cultures: A World View, BasicBooks, pp323-328 {{ISBN|0465045898}} Prior to independence Asians owned nearly three quarters of the private non-agricultural assets in the country.Leys, Colin, Underdevelopment in Kenya: The Political Economy of Neo-Colonialism, 1964-71, London, Heinemann, 1975, p.45 ==Independence== Kenya achieved independence from Britain in 1963, and thereafter followed a period of volatility in African and Asian relations. Asians, along with Europeans, were given two years to acquire Kenyan citizenship and surrender their [[British subject|British passports]]. Out of approximately 180,000 Asians and 42,000 Europeans in Kenya at the time, fewer than 20,000 had submitted their applications by the deadline.Donald Rothchild, Racial bargaining in independent Kenya (London, 1973), p. 188 This in turn led to growing animosity and distrust from Africans.They considered those who failed to take up Kenyan citizenship as being disloyal.Donald Rothchild, `Citizenship and national integration: the non-African crisis in Kenya', in Studies in race and nations (Center on International Race Relations, University of Denver working papers), 1}3 (1969±70), p. 1 Those without Kenyan citizenship soon became subject to increasing discrimination by the ruling government [[Jomo Kenyatta]]. Despite the entrepreneurial success of the community, in 1970, 70% of the economically active Asian population consisted of wage and salary earners, and 30% worked for the civil service. A policy of Africanisation meant many were sacked in favour of black Africans.Dharam P. Ghai, 'An Economic Survey' in Dharam P. Ghai, ed, Portrait of a Minority: Asians in East Africa, Nairobi, 1965, p.94 The Kenyan Immigration Act 1967 required Asians to acquire work permits, whilst a Trade Licensing Act passed in the same year limited the areas of the country in which non-Kenyans could engage in trade.Quest for equality (New Delhi, 1993), p. 99 In the late 1960s and early 1970s, faced with a dim future in Africa, many Asians choose to utilise their British passport and settle in the United Kingdom. Consequently, the Asian population in Kenya declined from 179,000 in 1962 to 139,000 in 1969 and to 78,000 in 1979.{{cite book|last1=Cohen|first1=edited by Robin|title=The Cambridge survey of world migration|date=1995|publisher=Cambridge Univ. Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9780521444057|page=71|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=YbzsBPuhyggC&oi=fnd&pg=PA356&dq=1947+%22partition+of+india%22+%22united+provinces%22++muhajir&ots=LjIm19rKU3&sig=nKoDKMWTLUpG4Rka1uYVUyRIPk4#v=onepage&q=muslim&f=false}} Asian migrants to the United Kingdom settled mainly in [[London]] and [[Leicester]]. ==Present day== Visiting Kenya in the 1970s, the Indo-Trinidadian writer [[V.S. Naipaul]] referring to the inward focus of the Asian community, commented that "the Indian in East Africa brought India with him and kept it inviolate".Naipaul, S. (1990).India: A million mutinies now London: William Heinemann Ltd Those who remained saw a gradual improvement in their legal status, however the Asian community continued to be cautiously inward and self-reliant. Despite varying degrees of acculturation, most have retained their strong Indian ties and traditions, and are a close-knit, [[Endogamy|endogamous]] community.{{cite book|last=Mwakikagile|first=Godfrey|title=Kenya: identity of a nation|year=2007|publisher=Godfrey Mwakikagile|isbn=0-9802587-9-0|pages=100–102|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=lsqjN-t6mP4C&pg=PA100#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Following the [[1982 Kenyan coup d'état attempt]] to remove [[Daniel arap Moi|President Moi]], many Asian shops and businesses in Nairobi were attacked and pillaged whilst a number of Asian women were said to have been raped by the rioters.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/01/world/a-fearful-reminder-lingers-for-asians-in-kenya.html|title=A fearful reminder lingers for Asians in Kenya|website=NY Times}} Despite fears at the time within the community, it did not result in another exodus of Asians from the country.Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 26 On 22 July 2017, the [[Uhuru Kenyatta]] government announced that the Asian community would be officially recognised as the 44th tribe in Kenya recognising the community's contribution to Kenya from the dawn of the nation.{{cite web|url=https://www.nation.co.ke/news/Hindu-officially-becomes-Kenya-s-44th-tribe/1056-4027242-12m5ygj/index.html|title=Kenya's-44th-tribe|website=The Nation}} ==Demography and religion== The 2009 Kenyan Census recorded 46,782 Kenyan citizens of Asian origin, while Asians without Kenyan citizenship numbered 35,009 individuals.{{cite web|title=Population and Housing Census – Ethnic Affiliation |url=http://www.knbs.or.ke/censusethnic.php |publisher=Kenya National Bureau of Statistics |accessdate=16 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121153548/http://www.knbs.or.ke/censusethnic.php |archivedate=21 November 2013 |df=dmy }} Asian ethnic groups mostly originate from a few select places in South Asia. The vast majority of Asians trace their ancestry to the regions of [[Gujarat]] and the [[Punjab (region)|Punjab]].Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 1 There are also large numbers who originate from [[Bombay]], [[Odisha]], [[Goa]] and [[Tamil Nadu]].{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=September 2018}} Notes: Traditional languages spoken by Asians include [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]], [[Hindustani language|Hindustani]], [[Marathi language|Marathi]], [[Konkani language|Konkani]], [[Kutchi language|Kutchi]], [[Odia language|Odia]], [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]].{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=September 2018}} Notes: The vast majority of Asians are [[Hindu]].{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=September 2018}} Notes: The leading caste-based subgroups within Kenyan Hinduism include Lohanas, Lohars, Rajput, Patels and Mehtas among others.Kinanga, Dr Moywaywa Charles, 'The Origins and Settlement of Hindus in Nairobi, Kenya' International Journal of Arts and Commerce Vol. 4 No. 8 October 2015, Page 119 Their largest concentration is in Nairobi city where [[Hindu temple|mandirs]] can be found in most neighbourhoods. The next largest community are [[Muslims]]; the majority being [[Sunni]] Muslims, however there is a significant [[Shia]] minority, including [[Ismailis]], [[Dawoodi Bohra|Bohras]] and [[Twelver|Ithnā'ashariyyah]].Oded, Arye, Islam and Politics in Kenya, Lynne Rienner Publishers, 2000, page 15 There are also sizeable communities of [[Sikhs]] and [[Jains]], and smaller numbers of [[Roman Catholics]]. {{Historical populations | title= Population census | percentages = pagr | align = none | cols = 2 |1911 |11,787 |1921 |25,253 |1931 |43,623 |1948 |97,687 |1962 |176,613 |1969 |139,037 |1979 |78,600 |1989 |89,185 |1999 |89,310 |2009 |81,791 |footnote = Post 1947 figures include those born in either India or Pakistan. |source = Herzig, Pascale, South Asians in Kenya: Gender, Generation and Changing Identities in Diaspora, LIT Verlag Münster, 2006, page 28Adam, Michael, Indian Africa: Minorities of Indian-Pakistani Origin in Eastern Africa, Mkuki na Nyota Publishers, 2015, page 170 }} ==See also== {{Portal|Kenya|India}} * [[List of Kenyan Asian people]] * [[Demographics of Kenya]] * [[Expulsion of Asians in Uganda in 1972]] * [[Indian diaspora in East Africa]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Bibliography== * [http://www.rudyfoto.com/IndiansofAfrica.html Indians of Africa], Rudy Brueggemann, 2000. * [http://www.goacom.com/news/news2000/mar/msg00094.html A New View of Kenya's 'Asians'], [[Washington Post]] 15 March 2000. * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/4/newsid_2738000/2738629.stm More Kenyan Asians flee to Britain]: BBC, 4 February 1968. Reprinted by BBC.co.uk, "On this Date", n.d. * [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/10423 The Lost Indians of Kenya], Salim Lone, New York Times Review of Books, Volume 17, Number 5 · 7 October 1971. * [http://www.shashitharoor.com/articles/hindu/kenyans.php 'We're all Kenyans here'], Shashi Tharoor, [[The Hindu]], 7 November 2004. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509141643/http://www.wairua.com/ruth/culture/africa.html The Indian Diaspora in Africa], Ruth DeSouza. * Vincent Cable The Asians of Kenya, African Affairs, Vol. 68, No. 272 (Jul. 1969), pp. 218–231 *Randall Hansen. THE KENYAN ASIANS, BRITISH POLITICS, AND THE COMMONWEALTH IMMIGRANTS ACT, 1968. The Historical Journal (1999), 42: 809–834 . *[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/RdLeaflet.asp?sLeafletID=400&j=1 Unfree Labour: Family History Sources for Indian Indentured Labour]. Research Guide from The [[British National Archives]], 2006. ==External links== *[http://asianafricanheritage.com/ Asian African Heritage Trust] *[http://www.lclark.edu/~peck/EAf-Orient/Kenya/Imperialism.htm KENYA, One Hundred Years of Political History in a Flash. Part II. Imperialism], Richard Peck, Lewis and Clark College, 2006. *[http://www.immigration.go.ke/ Immigration Department of Kenya], abstract history of nationality laws. *http://namaskar-africana.com ===Further reading=== * Adam, Michel. "A microcosmic minority: The Indo-Kenyans of Nairobi." In: Charton-Bigot, Hélène and Deyssi Rodriguez-Torres (editors). ''Nairobi Today: The Paradox of a Fragmented City''. [[African Books Collective]], 2010. start page 216. {{ISBN|9987080936}}, 9789987080939. The source edition is an English translation, published by Mkuki na Nyota Publishers Ltd. of [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]] in association with the French Institute for Research in Africa (IFRA) of Nairobi. The book was originally published in French as ''Nairobi contemporain: Les paradoxes d'une ville fragmentée'', [[Karthala Editions]] (''Hommes et sociétés'', ISSN 0993-4294). French version article is "[https://books.google.com/books?id=O9pTMVqVsQoC&pg=PA285&dq=%22Une+minorit%C3%A9+microcosmique+:+les+Indo-Kenyans+de+Nairobi%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=egobUpS6G4GY2AWD8YHgDw&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAA Une minorité microcosmique : les Indo-Kenyans de Nairobi]", p. 285-358. {{ISBN|2845867875}}, 9782845867871. * Robert Granville Gregory, India and East Africa: a history of race relations within the British Empire, 1890–1939 (Oxford, 1971) * J S Mangat, A history of the Asians in East Africa, c. 1886 to 1945 (Oxford, 1969) {{Ethnic groups in Kenya}} {{NRI-PIO}} [[Category:Kenyan people of Indian descent|*]] [[Category:Indian diaspora in Kenya| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Kenya]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2018}} '''Khalid Muhammad Ishaq ''' (16 August 1926 – 7 February 2004), [[Senior Advocate Supreme Court]], was a [[Pakistan]]i [[jurist]] and scholar of [[law]], [[Islamic studies]] and [[literature]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/140238|title=KARACHI: Khalid Ishaq remembered|date=22 May 2005|publisher=}}</ref>
==Education== Muhammad graduated with a degree in [[Arabic]] from [[D. J. Science College]] in 1945. He received the first position in [[Master of Arts|MA]] examinations given by the [[Bombay University]]. Later, he did his [[LLB]] at the SC [[Shahani Law College]].
==Life and career== Muhammad was born on August 16, 1926 in [[Shikarpur, Pakistan|Shikarpur]], [[Sindh]] to Mohammed Ishaq and Begum Talat Farrukh Ahmed Ishaq. His maternal grandfather was Maulvi Ziauddin Ahmed who was the first Indian to serve as DIG{{Clarify|reason=What is DIG?|date=January 2018}} of Bombay Sind Presidency.
Ishaq's first marriage was to an Italian lady. His second marriage was with Begum Khursheed Ishaq. He has two daughters and two sons. Ishaq started legal practice in 1948. In 1958, when he was only 32 years of age, he was appointed Additional [[Advocate General]] of [[West Pakistan]]. Five years later, he was promoted to [[Advocate General]]. In 1964, Ishaq stepped down from that position and established his own practice. He practiced [[Civil law (common law)|civil law]] in the [[High Court of Sindh]] and the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan]]. He became president of the High Court Bar Association in 1965. Ishaq died in [[Karachi]] in 2004.
==Scholarship== Since [[Islam]] was his inspiration, Ishaq's chief interest lay in [[Persian language|Persian]] and Arabic. In 1965, he became the project director of the [[Islamic Research Institute]]. He was a member of the [[Council of Islamic Ideology]] [[Pakistan]] from 1969 to 1972, and again from 1977 to 1980. Ishaq taught at the [[Sindh University]] from 1976 to 1977 as a [[Professor]] of [[Seerut-un-Nabi]]. He also appeared in scores of television programmes which dealt with [[legal]] and [[religious]] problems.
Ishaq had a large collection of commentaries on the [[Quran]]. His private library, until 1999, contained 175,000 volumes, making him the owner of one of the biggest collection of books in [[Pakistan]].{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} Many institutions requested that he donate his collection but he refused to part with his books. The books were donated to [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]] (LUMS) in 2005. [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]] (LUMS) has dedicated the first floor of its library as the "Khalid Ishaq Wing" in recognition of the massive donation of books.<ref>http://library.lums.edu.pk/atl_collections.html</ref>
==Students and associates== Men and women from Ishap's chambers have become leading jurists in their own right. Among his associates who were elevated to the superior judiciary were Justice Abdul Qadir Sheikh, Justice Amir Raza, Justice [[Nasir Aslam Zahid]], Justice [[Majida Rizvi]], the late Justice [[Nizam Ahmed]], Justice [[Sabihuddin Ahmed]], Justice [[Ghulam Nabi Soomro]], Justice [[Mujeebullah Siddiqui]], Justice [[Amir Hani Muslim]] and Justice [[Mushtaq Memon]].
Many students cite Khalid Ishaq as their mentor, teacher and colleague, including Abdul Hafeez Lakho, Muneer Malik, Shehenshah Hussain, Ahsan Zaheer Rizvi, Khalid Ibrahim, Abdul G. Soomro, Abid Zuberi, Faisal Kamal Alam, Arshad Hussain Khan, Ghulam Sarwar Jenjer, Muhammad Ehsan, Sohail Jabbar Malik and Khalid Ishaq's son, Sohaib Khalid Ishaq. [[Khalida Ghous]] did her [[Ph.D.]] thesis under his supervision.
An important feature of his life was the weekly meeting of 20 to 30 people at his home every Sunday from 9:00 AM to 1:00 PM. These meetings, which were held for almost 40 years and terminated only a few weeks before his death, were a kind of intellectual forum where the current issues were discussed freely. Among the regular participants were the journalists, Salahuddin, the editor of weekly ''Takbir'', Major Ibn ul-Hasan, a columnist of that time and Nusrat Mirza, educators Abd ul-Qadeer Saleem, Molana Amir Usmani and Molan Tasin and businessmen Riaz Shafi, and Saeed Ahmad of Anchor Shipping. Iqbal Shah DSP (r), a renowned Sind police officer unfairly{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} retired in Ayub Khan's martial law who was considered by Ishaq to be an expert in Allama Iqbal' s writings, attended these meetings as well.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.dawn.com/2004/02/13/letted.htm#1 Tribute to Khalid Ishaque] * [http://www.dawn.com/2005/05/22/local10.htm Khalid Ishaq remembered] * [http://www.dawn.com/2004/02/25/local13.htm Full court reference held for Khalid Ishaq] * [http://www.dawn.com/2004/02/10/local13.htm Khalid Ishaq's death condoled]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ishaq, Khalid M.}} [[Category:Sindhi people]] [[Category:Pakistani lawyers]] [[Category:Pakistani activists]] [[Category:Pakistani scholars]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:People from Shikarpur District]] [[Category:Lawyers from Karachi]]

This is a compilation of symbols commonly used in astronomy, particularly professional [[astronomy]].
==Age (stellar)== * τ - age
==Astrometry parameters== [[Astrometry]] parameters * R<sub>v</sub> - [[radial velocity]] * cz - apparent [[radial velocity]] * z - [[Redshift]] * μ - [[proper motion]] * π - [[parallax]] * J - [[Epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] * α - [[Right Ascension]] * δ - [[Declination]] * λ - [[Ecliptic longitude]] * β - [[Ecliptic latitude]] * l - [[Galactic longitude]] * b - [[Galactic latitude]]
==Cosmological parameters== [[Cosmology|Cosmological]] parameters * h - [[dimensionless Hubble parameter]] * H<sub>0</sub> - [[Hubble constant]] * Λ - [[cosmological constant]] * Ω - [[Friedmann equations|density parameter]] * ρ - [[Friedmann equations|density]] * ρ<sub>c</sub> - [[Friedmann equations|critical density]] * z - [[redshift]]
==Distance description== Distance description for orbital and non-orbital parameters: * d - distance ** d - in km = [[Kilometre|kilometer]] ** d - in mi = [[mile]] ** d - in AU = [[astronomical unit]] ** d - in ly = [[light-year]] ** d - in pc = [[parsec]] ** d - in kpc = kiloparsec (1000 pc) * D<sub>L</sub> - [[luminosity distance]], ''obtaining an objects distance using only visual aspects''
==Galaxy comparison== [[Galaxy]] type and spectral comparison: * see [[galaxy morphological classification]]
==Luminosity comparison== [[Luminosity]] comparison: * ''L''<sub>S</sub>, {{Solar luminosity}} - luminosity of the [[Sun]] (Sol)
Luminosity of certain object: * L<sub>acc</sub> - accretion luminosity * L<sub>bol</sub> - [[Luminosity#In astronomy|bolometric luminosity]]
==Mass comparison== [[Mass]] comparison: * ''M''<sub>E</sub>, {{Earth mass}} - mass of [[Earth]] * {{Jupiter mass}}, {{Jupiter mass|greek=y}}- mass of [[Jupiter]] * ''M''<sub>S</sub>, {{Solar mass}} - mass of the [[Sun]] (Sol)
Mass of certain object: * M<sub>●</sub><ref>[http://xxx.lanl.gov/abs/astro-ph/0611040 Ultra-luminous X-ray sources: X-ray binaries in a high/hard state?], Z. Kuncic, R. Soria, C. K. Hung, M. C. Freeland, G. V. Bicknell, 2006</ref> - mass of [[black hole]] * M<sub>acc</sub> - mass of [[accretion disc]]
==Metallicity comparison== [[Metallicity]] comparison: * [Fe/H] - Iron ratio to Hydrogen, ''a logarithm representation of the ratio of a star's iron abundance compared to that of the [[Sun]]'' * [M/H] - Metallicity ratio. * Z - Metallicity * Z<sub>S</sub>, Z<sub>☉</sub> - Metallicity of the [[Sun]] (Sol)
==Orbital parameters== [[Orbital elements|Orbital Parameters]] of a Cosmic Object: * α - [[Right ascension|RA]], ''right ascension, if the Greek letter does not appear, '''á''' letter will appear.'' * δ - [[Declination|Dec]], ''declination, if the Greek letter does not appear, '''ä''' letter will appear.'' * P or P<sub>orb</sub> - [[orbital period]] * a - [[semi-major axis]] * b - [[semi-minor axis]] * q - [[apsis|periapsis]], ''the minimum distance'' * Q - [[apsis]], ''the maximum distance'' * e - [[Orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] * i - [[inclination]] * Ω - [[longitude of the ascending node|longitude of ascending node]] * ω - [[argument of periapsis]] * R<sub>L</sub> - [[Roche lobe]] * M - [[Mean anomaly]] * M<sub>o</sub> - Mean anomaly at epoch
==Radius comparison== [[Radius]] comparison: * ''R''<sub>E</sub>, {{Earth radius}} - Radius compared to [[Earth]] * {{Jupiter radius}}, {{Jupiter radius|greek=y}}- Radius compared to [[Jupiter]] * ''R''<sub>S</sub>, {{Solar radius}} - Radius compared to The [[Sun]] (Sol)
==Spectral comparison== [[Astronomical spectroscopy|Spectral]] comparison: * see [[Stellar classification]] * m<sub>(object)</sub> - [[Apparent magnitude]] * M<sub>(object)</sub> - [[Absolute magnitude]], ''for galaxies and stars'' * H<sub>(object)</sub> - Absolute magnitude, ''for planets and nonstellar objects''
==Temperature description== [[Temperature]] description: * [[Effective temperature|T<sub>eff</sub>]] - Temperature Effect, ''usually associated with luminous object'' * T<sub>max</sub> - Temperature Maximum, ''usually associated with non-luminous object'' * T<sub>avg</sub> - Temperature Average, ''usually associated with non-luminous object'' * T<sub>min</sub> - Temperature Minimum, ''usually associated with non-luminous object'' * [[Kelvin|K]] - Kelvin
==See also== * [[List of astronomy acronyms]] * [[Astronomical symbols]] * [[Stellar classification]] * [[Galaxy morphological classification]] * [[List of astronomical catalogues]] * [[Glossary of astronomy]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Astronomy-related lists|Symbols]] [[Category:Lists of symbols|Astronomy]]

revision.text:
'''Mohil''', '''Mial''','''Moyal''' or '''Mohal''' is a branch of the [[Chauhan]] [[Rajput]]s,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=ESqxTZaKDoPEvgOO-JWJBw&ct=result&id=JDW2AAAAIAAJ&dq=mohil+rajputs&q=mohil+ Imperial gazetteer of India ... – Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>Imperial gazetteer of India: provincial series, Volume 23</ref> and one of the [[gotra]]s of [[Yadav]]as.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=QJNHAAAAMAAJ&q=mohil+ahirs&dq=mohil+ahirs&hl=en&ei=5DGxTcu8IYa6vQPX8ZCFBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw Yadavas through the ages, from ... – Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[[Yadav]]as through the ages, from ancient period to date, Volume 2</ref> British historians H.A. Rose, Ibbetson and Maclagan claim Mohals are a gotra of [[Yaduvanshi Ahirs]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1QmrSwFYe60C&pg=PA6&dq=aheer++punjab&hl=en&ei=U3EDTfWGJMzHrQfZp-mQDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=mohal&f=false Glossary of the Tribes and Castes of ... – Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>Glossary of the Tribes and Castes of the Punjab and North West Frontier Province By H.A. Rose, IBBETSON, Maclagan</ref>
==History== The Mohils are believed to have been, like the Qiyam Kjanis, converts from the Mohil branch of the Chauhan Rajputs; this is mentioned in inscriptions and [[Rajasthani people|Rajasthani]] kyat literature. Mohils were called by the name of their ancestor, Mohil, to distinguish them from others. Reference to this can be found in an inscription of his son, [[Rana (title)|Rana]] Hathad or Hardatt, dated v.s 1162 (A.D.1105) According to bardic sources such as the khyat of Muhnot Nainsi, Hathad was fifth in the line of the ruling family of [[Eastern Ganga Dynasty|Ganga]] or Dhandha through the latter's son [[Indra]], while another bardic account make the Mohils descendants of Vachhra or Kanha, both sons of Ganga. <ref>Director (Muslim Epigraphy), Archaeological Survey of India, Nagpur.</ref>
== Location ==
The Mohil Chauhans possibly ruled over the Chhapar-Dronapur, Ladnun parganas, which are near modern Gopalpur in the [[Churu]] District of [[Rajasthan]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=YjGxTYebM5CYvAOdtdSRBw&ct=result&id=AZIMAQAAMAAJ&dq=mohil+rajputs&q=mohil Mediaeval history of Rajasthan – Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>Mediaeval history of Rajasthan, Volume 1</ref>
According to some contemporary sources<!-- needs references -->Chhapar -Dronapur was conquered by the [[Rathod]]s of [[Jodhpur]] in 1474 A.D., but the Ladnun pargana continued to be held by the Mohil chiefs, one of whom was Rao Jai Singh, granted land to a bard, Jasudan, son of the poet Samaur Teja.<!-- needs references -->
==Conversion to Islam==
According to local tradition, the ruler of Ladaun region, [[Raja|Rao]] Jai Singh, was once watching a group of women passing through the town gate to fetch water. A menacing bull blocked the road. One of the women, who was a [[Muslim]], took the bull in hand and pushed it out of the way. The Rao was greatly impressed by the woman's show of courage and valour. Thinking that the offspring of such a brave woman would be as brave, the Raja formally proposed marriage with her to her father. The girl gave her consent on the condition that the Raja became a Muslim. The Raja converted, whereupon the marriage was solemnised. Later, the girl discovered the Raja had not given up his faith, but merely pretended to have become a Muslim and was regularly visiting [[temple]]s. She sent a message to the [[Delhi]] Sultan, who invaded Ladnun, defeated the [[Raja]], and forced him to convert to [[Islam]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nKJiBUFrmfoC&pg=RA1-PA122&dq=mohil+rajputs&hl=en&ei=ESqxTZaKDoPEvgOO-JWJBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=mohil%20rajputs&f=false Cultural contours of India: Dr ... – Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>Cultural contours of India: Dr. Satya Prakash felicitation volume By Satya Prakash, Vijai Shankar Śrivastava</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox religious building |building_name= Moscow Cathedral Mosque |image= Moscow Cathedral Mosque 01-2016.jpg |caption= The mosque in 2016 |coordinates= {{coord|55|46|45|N|37|37|37|E|region:RU_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |location= {{flag|Russia}}
{{flag|Moscow}} |geo= |religious_affiliation=[[Islam]] |district= |functional_status=Active |leadership= |website=http://www.mihrab.ru/ |architecture_type= Mosque |architecture_style= |facade_direction= |year_completed= 1904 (old structure)
2015 (current structure) |construction_cost= |specifications=yes |architect= Nikolay Zhukov |capacity= 10,000 |length= |width= |width_nave= |height_max= |dome_quantity= |dome_height_outer= |dome_height_inner= |dome_dia_outer= |dome_dia_inner= |minaret_quantity= |minaret_height= |spire_quantity= |spire_height= |materials= }} [[File:Moscow Cathedral Mosque 2009.jpg|thumb|The historic Cathedral Mosque surrounded by the construction site of the new mosque (2009)]] [[File:Moscow Cathedral Mosque interior 01-2016 img3.jpg|thumb|Central hall with a dome]] '''Moscow Cathedral Mosque''' ({{lang-ru| Московская соборная мечеть}}, ''Moskovskaya sobornaya mechet'') is the [[Jama Masjid|main mosque]] of [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. It is located on [[Olimpiysky Avenue (Moscow)|Olimpiysky Avenue]], close to the [[Olympic Stadium (Moscow)|Olympic Stadium]] in the centre of the city. == History == The original structure was built in 1904 according to the design of the architect [[Nikolay Zhukov]] and has undergone some reconstructions since then. It was also sometimes called "Tatar Mosque" because its congregation consisted mainly of ethnic [[Tatars]]. Socially, the Moscow Congregational Mosque was often viewed as the central mosque in Russia. It was one of the four mosques in Moscow. The old mosque was demolished on 11 September 2011. The decision to demolish it was controversial.{{cite news|last=Krainova |first=Natalya|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/historic-mosque-demolished-on-911-anniversary/443617.html|title=Historic Mosque Demolished on 9/11 Anniversary|work=The Moscow Times|date=13 September 2011|accessdate=4 July 2016}} In June 2008, the mosque was recognized as an object of cultural heritage, however, in the end of 2008 it was removed from the list of historical and architectural monuments. Thus, at the time of demolition, it was not protected.{{cite web|url=http://echo.msk.ru/programs/kulshok/812423-echo/|script-title=ru:Зачем снесли Соборную мечеть?|date=17 September 2011|publisher=Echo of Moscow|language=ru|accessdate=21 September 2011}} There were plans to reconstruct the mosque, and the reconstruction project was designed by architect [[Ilyas Tazhiyev]]. One of the reasons for reconstruction was that the building deviated by several degrees from the direction to [[Mecca]]. The project included disassembling the mosque, collecting all the stones, and re-assembling it again with corrected orientation. In 2009, however, the [[Russian Council of Muftis|Council of Muftis]] dismissed Tazhiyev, first claiming they will make another reconstruction project, and then demolishing the building claiming it was close to collapse. Tazhiyev stated after the demolition that the reconstruction was still possible, and the building was not close to collapse. The Moscow Cathedral Mosque became the first demolished religious building in Moscow since 1978. ==New mosque== A new mosque has been built at the site of the former one. It was officially inaugurated on 23 September 2015. The new mosque has the capacity of ten thousand worshippers. Presidents [[Vladimir Putin]] of Russia, [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] of Turkey and [[Mahmoud Abbas]] of the Palestinian Territories together with local Muslim leaders participated in the inauguration ceremony of this mosque.{{cite web|url=http://en.shabestan.ir/detail/News/35834|title=Central mosque of Moscow will be inaugurated in 23rd September|publisher= Shabestan News Agency|date=19 September 2015|accessdate=22 September 2015}} ==See also== *[[Islam in Russia]] *[[List of mosques in Russia]] ==References== {{portal|Islam|Moscow}} ==External links== *{{Commonscat-inline}} * {{ru icon}} {{official website|http://www.mihrab.ru/}} * {{ru icon}} [http://gov.cap.ru/hierarhy.asp?page=./55485/61527/61528/67953 History of Moscow Cathedral Mosque] * {{ru icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929131959/http://religion.ng.ru/people/2004-05-26/3_islam.html The Mosque of all Russia] * [http://www.russian-mosques.com/ Russian mosques] {{Mosques in Russia}} [[Category:1904 establishments in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:2011 disestablishments in Russia]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Russia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures demolished in 2011]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in Russia]] [[Category:Destroyed mosques]] [[Category:Meshchansky District]] [[Category:Mosques in Moscow]] [[Category:Mosques completed in 1904]] [[Category:Mosques completed in 2015]] [[Category:Tatar culture]] [[Category:20th-century mosques]] [[Category:21st-century mosques]] [[Category:Religious buildings with domes]]
